trans-unit.source: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.
trans-unit.target: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.

trans-unit.source: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
trans-unit.target: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

trans-unit.source: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps
trans-unit.target: Deploying and debugging Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.
trans-unit.target: This article guides you through the steps to target various deployment and debugging targets.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Visual Studio allows you to deploy and debug your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps on a variety of Windows 10 devices.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Visual Studio allows you to deploy and debug your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps on a variety of Windows 10 devices.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio will handle the process of building and registering the application on the target device.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio will handle the process of building and registering the application on the target device.

trans-unit.source: Picking a deployment target
trans-unit.target: Picking a deployment target

trans-unit.source: To pick a target, navigate to the debug target dropdown next to the **Start Debugging** button and select which target you want to deploy your application to.
trans-unit.target: To pick a target, navigate to the debug target dropdown next to the **Start Debugging** button and select which target you want to deploy your application to.

trans-unit.source: After the target is selected, choose **Start Debugging (F5)** to deploy and debug on that target, or press **Ctrl+F5** to just deploy to that target.
trans-unit.target: After the target is selected, choose **Start Debugging (F5)** to deploy and debug on that target, or press **Ctrl+F5** to just deploy to that target.

trans-unit.source: **Local Machine** will deploy the application to your current development machine.
trans-unit.target: **Local Machine** will deploy the application to your current development machine.

trans-unit.source: This option is only available if your application's **Target Platform Min. Version** is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.
trans-unit.target: This option is only available if your application's **Target Platform Min. Version** is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.

trans-unit.source: **Simulator** will deploy the application to a simulated environment on your current development machine.
trans-unit.target: **Simulator** will deploy the application to a simulated environment on your current development machine.

trans-unit.source: This option is only available if your application's **Target Platform Min. Version** is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.
trans-unit.target: This option is only available if your application's **Target Platform Min. Version** is less than or equal to the operating system on your development machine.

trans-unit.source: **Device** will deploy the application to a USB connected device.
trans-unit.target: **Device** will deploy the application to a USB connected device.

trans-unit.source: The device must be developer unlocked and have the screen unlocked.
trans-unit.target: The device must be developer unlocked and have the screen unlocked.

trans-unit.source: An **Emulator** target will boot up and deploy the application to an emulator with the configuration specified in the name.
trans-unit.target: An **Emulator** target will boot up and deploy the application to an emulator with the configuration specified in the name.

trans-unit.source: Emulators are only available on Hyper-V enabled machines running Windows 8.1 or beyond.
trans-unit.target: Emulators are only available on Hyper-V enabled machines running Windows 8.1 or beyond.

trans-unit.source: **Remote Machine** will let you specify a remote target to deploy the application.
trans-unit.target: **Remote Machine** will let you specify a remote target to deploy the application.

trans-unit.source: More information about deploying to a remote machine can be found in [Specifying a remote device](#specifying-a-remote-device).
trans-unit.target: More information about deploying to a remote machine can be found in [Specifying a remote device](#specifying-a-remote-device).

trans-unit.source: Specifying a remote device
trans-unit.target: Specifying a remote device

trans-unit.source: C# and Microsoft Visual Basic
trans-unit.target: C# and Microsoft Visual Basic

trans-unit.source: To specify a remote machine for C# or Microsoft Visual Basic apps, select **Remote Machine** in the debug target dropdown.
trans-unit.target: To specify a remote machine for C# or Microsoft Visual Basic apps, select **Remote Machine** in the debug target dropdown.

trans-unit.source: The **Remote Connections** dialog will appear which will let you specify an IP Address or select a discovered device.
trans-unit.target: The **Remote Connections** dialog will appear which will let you specify an IP Address or select a discovered device.

trans-unit.source: By default, the **Universal** authentication mode is selected.
trans-unit.target: By default, the **Universal** authentication mode is selected.

trans-unit.source: To determine which authentication mode to use, see [Authentication modes](#authentication-modes).
trans-unit.target: To determine which authentication mode to use, see [Authentication modes](#authentication-modes).

trans-unit.source: To return to this dialog, you can open project properties and navigate to the **Debug** tab.
trans-unit.target: To return to this dialog, you can open project properties and navigate to the **Debug** tab.

trans-unit.source: From there, select **Find…**
trans-unit.target: From there, select **Find…**

trans-unit.source: next to **Remote machine:**
trans-unit.target: next to **Remote machine:**

trans-unit.source: To deploy an application to a remote PC, you will also need to download and install the Visual Studio Remote Tools on the target PC.
trans-unit.target: To deploy an application to a remote PC, you will also need to download and install the Visual Studio Remote Tools on the target PC.

trans-unit.source: See [Remote PC instructions](#remote-pc-instructions) for full instructions.
trans-unit.target: See [Remote PC instructions](#remote-pc-instructions) for full instructions.

trans-unit.source: C++ and JavaScript
trans-unit.target: C++ and JavaScript

trans-unit.source: To specify a remote machine target for a C++ or JavaScript UWP app, go to project properties by right clicking on the project in the **Solution Explorer**, and clicking **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: To specify a remote machine target for a C++ or JavaScript UWP app, go to project properties by right clicking on the project in the **Solution Explorer**, and clicking **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to **Debugging** settings and change **Debugger to launch** to **Remote Machine**.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to **Debugging** settings and change **Debugger to launch** to **Remote Machine**.

trans-unit.source: Then fill in the **Machine Name** (or click **Locate…**
trans-unit.target: Then fill in the **Machine Name** (or click **Locate…**

trans-unit.source: to find one) and set the **Authentication Type** property.
trans-unit.target: to find one) and set the **Authentication Type** property.

trans-unit.source: After the machine is specified, you can select **Remote Machine** in the debug target dropdown to return to that specified machine.
trans-unit.target: After the machine is specified, you can select **Remote Machine** in the debug target dropdown to return to that specified machine.

trans-unit.source: Only one remote machine can be selected at a time.
trans-unit.target: Only one remote machine can be selected at a time.

trans-unit.source: Remote PC instructions
trans-unit.target: Remote PC instructions

trans-unit.source: To deploy to a remote PC, the target PC must have the Visual Studio Remote Tools installed.
trans-unit.target: To deploy to a remote PC, the target PC must have the Visual Studio Remote Tools installed.

trans-unit.source: The remote PC must also be running a version of Windows that is greater than or equal to your apps **Target Platform Min. Version** property.
trans-unit.target: The remote PC must also be running a version of Windows that is greater than or equal to your apps **Target Platform Min. Version** property.

trans-unit.source: Once you have installed the remote tools, you must launch the remote debugger on the target PC.
trans-unit.target: Once you have installed the remote tools, you must launch the remote debugger on the target PC.

trans-unit.source: To do this, search for **Remote Debugger** in the **Start** menu launch it, and if prompted allow the debugger to configure your firewall settings.
trans-unit.target: To do this, search for **Remote Debugger** in the **Start** menu launch it, and if prompted allow the debugger to configure your firewall settings.

trans-unit.source: By default, the debugger launches with Windows authentication.
trans-unit.target: By default, the debugger launches with Windows authentication.

trans-unit.source: This will require user credentials if the logged in user is not the same on both PCs.
trans-unit.target: This will require user credentials if the logged in user is not the same on both PCs.

trans-unit.source: To change it to **No authentication**, go to **Tools** -> **Options** in the **Remote Debugger** and set it to **No Authentication**.
trans-unit.target: To change it to **No authentication**, go to **Tools** -> **Options** in the **Remote Debugger** and set it to **No Authentication**.

trans-unit.source: Once the remote debugger is setup, you can deploy from your development machine.
trans-unit.target: Once the remote debugger is setup, you can deploy from your development machine.

trans-unit.source: For more information see the [Remote Tools for Visual Studio]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=717039) download page.
trans-unit.target: For more information see the [Remote Tools for Visual Studio]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=717039) download page.

trans-unit.source: Authentication modes
trans-unit.target: Authentication modes

trans-unit.source: There are three authentication modes for remote machine deployment:
trans-unit.target: There are three authentication modes for remote machine deployment:

trans-unit.source: **Universal (Unencrypted Protocol)**: Use this authentication mode whenever you are deploying to a remote device that is not a Windows PC (desktop or laptop).
trans-unit.target: **Universal (Unencrypted Protocol)**: Use this authentication mode whenever you are deploying to a remote device that is not a Windows PC (desktop or laptop).

trans-unit.source: Currently, this is only IoT devices.
trans-unit.target: Currently, this is only IoT devices.

trans-unit.source: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) should only be used on trusted networks.
trans-unit.target: Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) should only be used on trusted networks.

trans-unit.source: The debugging connection is vulnerable to malicious users who could intercept and change data being passed between the development and remote machine.
trans-unit.target: The debugging connection is vulnerable to malicious users who could intercept and change data being passed between the development and remote machine.

trans-unit.source: **Windows**: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).
trans-unit.target: **Windows**: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).

trans-unit.source: Use this authentication mode when you have access to the credentials of the logged in user of the target machine.
trans-unit.target: Use this authentication mode when you have access to the credentials of the logged in user of the target machine.

trans-unit.source: This is the most secure channel for remote deployment.
trans-unit.target: This is the most secure channel for remote deployment.

trans-unit.source: **None**: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).
trans-unit.target: **None**: This authentication mode is only intended to be used for remote PC deployment (desktop or laptop).

trans-unit.source: Use this authentication mode when you have a test machine setup in an environment that has a test account logged in and you cannot enter the credentials.
trans-unit.target: Use this authentication mode when you have a test machine setup in an environment that has a test account logged in and you cannot enter the credentials.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the remote debugger settings are set to accept no authentication.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the remote debugger settings are set to accept no authentication.

trans-unit.source: Debugging options
trans-unit.target: Debugging options

trans-unit.source: On Windows 10, the startup performance of UWP apps is improved by proactively launching and then suspending apps in a technique called [prelaunch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Mt593297).
trans-unit.target: On Windows 10, the startup performance of UWP apps is improved by proactively launching and then suspending apps in a technique called [prelaunch](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Mt593297).

trans-unit.source: Many applications will not need to do anything special to work in this mode, but some applications may need to adjust their behavior.
trans-unit.target: Many applications will not need to do anything special to work in this mode, but some applications may need to adjust their behavior.

trans-unit.source: To help debug any issues in these code paths you can start debugging the app from Visual Studio in prelaunch mode.
trans-unit.target: To help debug any issues in these code paths you can start debugging the app from Visual Studio in prelaunch mode.

trans-unit.source: Debugging is supported both from a Visual Studio project (**Debug** -> **Other Debug Targets** -> **Debug Universal Windows App Prelaunch**), and for apps already installed on the machine (**Debug** -> **Other Debug Targets** -> **Debug Installed App Package**, and check the box for **Activate app with Prelaunch**).
trans-unit.target: Debugging is supported both from a Visual Studio project (**Debug** -> **Other Debug Targets** -> **Debug Universal Windows App Prelaunch**), and for apps already installed on the machine (**Debug** -> **Other Debug Targets** -> **Debug Installed App Package**, and check the box for **Activate app with Prelaunch**).

trans-unit.source: For more information read about how to [Debug UWP Prelaunch]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=717245).
trans-unit.target: For more information read about how to [Debug UWP Prelaunch]( http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=717245).

trans-unit.source: You can set the following deployment options on the **Debug** property page of the startup project.
trans-unit.target: You can set the following deployment options on the **Debug** property page of the startup project.

trans-unit.source: Allow Network Loopback
trans-unit.target: Allow Network Loopback

trans-unit.source: For security reasons, a UWP app that is installed in the standard manner is not allowed to make network calls to the device it is installed on.
trans-unit.target: For security reasons, a UWP app that is installed in the standard manner is not allowed to make network calls to the device it is installed on.

trans-unit.source: By default, Visual Studio deployment creates an exemption from this rule for the deployed app.
trans-unit.target: By default, Visual Studio deployment creates an exemption from this rule for the deployed app.

trans-unit.source: This exemption allows you to test communication procedures on a single machine.
trans-unit.target: This exemption allows you to test communication procedures on a single machine.

trans-unit.source: Before submitting your app to the Windows Store, you should test your app without the exemption.
trans-unit.target: Before submitting your app to the Windows Store, you should test your app without the exemption.

trans-unit.source: To remove the network loopback exemption from the app:
trans-unit.target: To remove the network loopback exemption from the app:

trans-unit.source: On the C# and Visual Basic **Debug** property page, clear the **Allow Network Loopback** check box.
trans-unit.target: On the C# and Visual Basic **Debug** property page, clear the **Allow Network Loopback** check box.

trans-unit.source: On the JavaScript and C++ **Debugging** property page, set the **Allow Network Loopback** value to **No**.
trans-unit.target: On the JavaScript and C++ **Debugging** property page, set the **Allow Network Loopback** value to **No**.

trans-unit.source: Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts (C# and Visual Basic) / Launch App (JavaScript and C++)
trans-unit.target: Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts (C# and Visual Basic) / Launch App (JavaScript and C++)

trans-unit.source: To configure the deployment to automatically start a debugging session when the app is launched:
trans-unit.target: To configure the deployment to automatically start a debugging session when the app is launched:

trans-unit.source: On the C# and Visual Basic **Debug** property page, check the **Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts** check box.
trans-unit.target: On the C# and Visual Basic **Debug** property page, check the **Do not launch, but debug my code when it starts** check box.

trans-unit.source: On the JavaScript and C++ **Debugging** property page, set the **Launch Application** value to **Yes**.
trans-unit.target: On the JavaScript and C++ **Debugging** property page, set the **Launch Application** value to **Yes**.
